--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> > I wonder if=
 this would be useful functionality for JUnit to
> > have in general: when =
a test class is detected, and that test class has
> > non-static inner clas=
ses which may themselves be test classes, when
> > building up tests for th=
e enclosing class, also instantiate the inner
> > test classes and attach t=
o the (an?) enclosing test class instance. I
> > saw some previous discussi=
on about such fixtures in JDave.
> 
> I think there were two different dire=
ctions going on here.  It sounds
> like you want JUnit, when given the oute=
r class, to automatically
> instantiate the inner classes.  It sounded like=
 JDave wanted JUnit,
> when given the inner class, to automatically consult=
 the outer class
> when instantiating.
> 
> Am I getting both requests righ=
t?  If not, then we're getting close to
> a Rule of Three threshold for reu=
se.  If I am, then I see the same
> Java idiom having two different "obviou=
s" interpretations to two
> different classes of user.

David, I believe yo=
u're getting both requests right.  In my case, the inner classes are to be =
instantiated along with the enclosing class when the enclosing class is run=
, but never instantiated and run on their own.  I ended up accomplishing th=
is via the AllTests runner and suite() methods that adapt the enclosing cla=
ss and inner class instances as JUnit 3.8-style Test adapters.  I also want=
ed to tie the inner class instances to a specific enclosing class instance,=
 because the inner classes use fixture fields from an enclosing instance.

=
It looks as though the requirement for JDave inner class contexts is that t=
hey be instantiable and runnable on their own, independent of their sibling=
 contexts -- and that the requestor would have liked for such contexts to a=
dopt whatever Runner a @RunWith on the enclosing class might have specified=
.

Off the top of my head, I can't think of a clean way for JUnit to suppor=
t both strategies in the core proper.

I may try satisfying my specific use=
 case in another way, perhaps using an as-yet-developed kind of Runner.  Th=
e AllTests way still seems a bit icky, but works for now.

Thanks,
Paul Hol=
